questions.text: The skin colour in humans is influenced by all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The number of melanocytes is constant across all races and genders and doesn't play a role in skin colour.

  • Melanin is the primary determinant of human skin colour.

Determinants of Skin Colour

  • Activity of melanocytes
  • The ratio of eumelanin to pheomelanin
  • Efficiency of melanin transfer to keratinocytes
  • Genetics and UV exposure

Melanogenesis occurs in melanocytes, specifically in organelles called melanosomes.

  • Tyrosinase activity is the main control point in melanogenesis.
  • Influenced by UV radiation, α-MSH, ACTH, and genetic mutations

questions.text: What is the ratio of the epidermal melanin unit?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • One melanocyte is associated with approximately 36 surrounding keratinocytes through its dendrites. The entire unit is referred to as the "epidermal melanin unit."
  • "Epidermal melanin unit" of melanocytes located in the stratum basale layer of the skin and associated with the surrounding keratinocytes.
  • The dendrites of melanocytes are projected into the epidermis, where they transfer melanosomes to keratinocytes.
  • Approximately every tenth cell in the basal layer is a melanocyte.

choices.text: Type 4 has the highest cancer risk

questions.text: All are true about Fitzpatrick skin type except :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to the Fitzpatrick scale is a numerical classification schema for human skin types, Type 4 does not have the highest cancer risk.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with light brown, symmetrical macules over both cheeks, gradually developed over the past 5 years as given in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Light brown, symmetrical macules over both cheeks, that developed over a long period and the image given suggests melasma

Explanations for other options:

Melanocytic nevi (Option A): These are benign proliferations of melanocytes, the pigment-producing cells in the skin.

Photodermatitis (Option C): It is a skin reaction triggered or worsened by exposure to sunlight, especially ultraviolet (UV) radiation.

Cafe-au lait spots (Option D): These are Large, pigmented, coffee-brown colored macules associated with neurofibromatosis type 1, McCune-Albright syndrome, Triad - Segmental Calms, Precocious puberty, Polycystic fibrous dysplasia of bones.

questions.text: A patient with fever and joint pain for which NSAIDs were taken, now presents with brownish pigmentation on the nose as shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fever and joint pain followed by brownish pigmentation on the nose is the classical Chik Sign; the presence of Chik Sign is a useful retrospective clinical marker for prior Chikungunya infection, especially in endemic areas.

Chik Sign

Definition

  • Chik sign refers to striking brownish post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation over the centrofacial area(especially the nose), also referred to as “Brownie nose”.
  • May persist for up to 6 months after resolution of the acute illness.

Etiology

  • Caused by Chikungunya fever, an acute febrile illness due to an arbovirus (RNA virus of the Togaviridae family) transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes.

Clinical Features of Chikungunya

  • Acute high-grade fever with debilitating polyarthralgia/arthritis, headache, rash, and myalgia
  • Conjunctivitis and maculopapular eruptions may occur
  • NSAIDs are commonly used for joint pain and myalgia

Pathogenesis

  • Mechanism: Increased intraepidermal melanin retention or dispersion triggered by the viral illness
  • Occurs as part of post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH)

Differential Diagnosis

  • Dengue fever can occasionally produce a similar centrofacial pigmentation, but it's less common than in chikungunya.

Explanation for other options:

Melasma: (Option A) Hyperpigmentation usually symmetrical on cheeks, forehead; not associated with fever or NSAIDs.

Fixed Drug Eruption: (Option B) Presents as well-defined dusky red patches that recur at the same site after drug exposure, not typically limited to the nose.

Typhoid: (Option D)  May cause rose spots (faint salmon-colored rash), not brownish pigmentation on the nose.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in treatment of melasma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tacrolimus is an immunosuppressive drug that is used to lower the risk of organ rejection after transplantation. It is a calcineurin inhibitor and is not used in the treatment of melasma.

Treatment of Melasma: 

  • The application of chemical agents to cause controlled destruction of skin layers, leading to exfoliation, removal of pigment, and regeneration of new skin, is called chemical peeling.
  • Chemical peeling removes excess melanin by inducing a chemical burn and promotes epidermal turnover and melanin dispersion.

questions.text: Sunscreen lotions contain which of the following components:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Zinc oxide is the main component in sunscreens

Sunscreens are medications used topically or systemically to block ultraviolet rays

Reference:

Introduction to Sunscreens and Their UV Filters

questions.text: Which of the following is not nevus of melanocyte?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Becker's nevus is not a nevus of a melanocyte

Becker Nevus

  • Appears as a hyperpigmented patch with increased hair growth, caused by epidermal hyperpigmentation and increased androgen receptors, and not of melanocytic origin
  • Melanocytic nevi are lesions composed of nevus cells derived from melanocytes. Most are pigmented and appear due to the proliferation of these melanocytes or related cells.

Types of Naevi

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with a gradually developing, well-defined, hyperpigmented patch over the upper chest, first noticed 2 years ago. The lesion is asymptomatic and slowly increasing in size. Based on the history and image provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given history and the image attributed to the diagnosis of Becker’s Nevus 

Explanation for other options:

Fixed Drug Eruption (Option B): Presents as well-defined dusky red patches that recur at the same site after drug exposure, not present like the given image.

Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (Option C): Occurs after skin injury/inflammation (acne, eczema, trauma) as brown or black macules/patches at the site of the previous lesion. The pigmentation is not seasonal and localised to sun-exposed areas.

Congenital melanocytic nevus (Option D): CMN is a benign skin lesion present at birth, resulting from a proliferation of nevomelanocytes. These nevi typically appear as well-defined, round, or ovoid pigmented patches, usually uniformly brown to black. A characteristic feature, especially in larger lesions, is hypertrichosis (excess pigmented hair growth). The giant CMN subtype carries a higher risk of malignant melanoma, warranting regular monitoring.

questions.text: Which of the following is a disorder of hypopigmentation?
questions.solution: Explanation:

choices.text: It is a type of vitiligo

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with a hypopigmented patch that has been present since birth and has remained stable. There is no history of progression. Based on this history and image, which of the following is most accurate about the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image represents a child with piebaldism, which is caused by a mutation in the KIT proto-oncogene.

  • Definition: A rare, congenital disorder of pigmentation characterised by stable, well-demarcated depigmented patches of skin and hair.
  • Cause: Autosomal dominant disorder affecting melanocyte migration and development, characterised by isolated congenital leukoderma (white skin) and poliosis (white hair) in a distinct ventral midline pattern.
  • Clinical Features:
    1. Present at birth
    2. White forelock (poliosis) is a hallmark (present in up to 90% of cases)
    3. Symmetrical depigmented patches on the forehead, central chest, abdomen, and extremities
    4. Surrounding or interspersed islands of normally pigmented or hyperpigmented skin
  • Histology: Absent melanocytes in the depigmented areas

Explanation for other options:

X-linked recessive inheritance (Option A): Piebaldism is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

Type of vitiligo (Option B): Vitiligo is acquired and often progressive. Unlike congenital piebaldism, it is caused by an autoimmune disorder affecting melanocytes.

Caused by tyrosinase deficiency (Option C): This is characteristic of albinism, which is a genetic condition characterised by a lack of or reduced melanin, the pigment that determines skin, hair, and eye colour.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the OPD with clinical image as shown and eyes that rapidly dart side-to-side. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A 6-year-old boy with eyes that rapidly dart side-to-side is showing signs of nystagmus, which in the context of the given image is diagnosed as oculocutaneous albinism. In OCA, tyrosinase-positive positive have less severity.

Oculocutaneous Albinism

Inheritance

  • Autosomal recessive (Option A ruled out)

Basic Defect

  • Defective melanin synthesis due to enzyme mutations, mainly:
    • Tyrosinase (TYR): essential for converting tyrosine to melanin.
    • So, Tyrosinase-positive has less severity (Option B)
  • Melanocytes are present, but non-functional in melanin production. (Option D ruled out)

Clinical Features

  • At birth: White skin, white/blond hair, light irises
  • Eye findings:
    • Nystagmus (rapid eye movement)
    • Photophobia
    • Foveal hypoplasia
    • Reduced visual acuity
  • Skin findings:
    • Hypopigmented skin
    • No tanning (Option C ruled out)

Types of OCA

questions.text: Which of the following drugs plays a role in the chemoprevention of skin malignancies associated with a disorder from the given image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image contains a child with oculocutaneous albinism. Retinoids like isotretinoin are effective as chemopreventive agents in premalignant lesions of the skin.

  • Incidences of Squamous cell carcinoma, Basal cell carcinoma, and Actinic keratosis are markedly increased in patients with oculocutaneous albinism.
  • Interestingly, although rare cases of malignant melanoma are reported in these patients, the incidence does not appear to be markedly elevated.
  • If retinoids are given at an early stage, they can cause regression of premalignant lesions of the skin.
  • These can be recommended as they reduce the potential effects of carcinogenesis.

Explanation for other options:

Imiquimod (Option A): A topical immune response modifier used to treat existing actinic keratosis and superficial BCC.

Vismodegib (Option C): A hedgehog pathway inhibitor used for the treatment of advanced BCC, not for prevention.

5-Fluorouracil (5-FU) (Option D): A topical treatment for actinic keratosis and superficial skin cancers.

questions.text: Melanocytes are reduced in number in all of the following disorders except :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Melanocytes are normal in number but with no melanin production in Albinism

Albinism

  • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive
  • Defect: Tyrosinase enzyme deficiency - impaired melanin synthesis
  • Clinical Features:
    1. Skin: White skin, photosensitivity, prone to sunburn
    2. Hair: Golden-white
    3. Eyes: Blue/pale iris, photophobia, nystagmus, reduced visual acuity (due to foveal hypoplasia)
    4. Increased risk: Skin cancers – BCC, SCC, malignant melanoma

Explanation for other options:

Piebaldism (Option B): It is a congenital absence of melanocytes in patches of skin and hair due to a defect in the migration and differentiation of melanocytes.

Vitiligo (Option C): An autoimmune destruction of melanocytes, leading to complete depigmentation of the affected areas.

Chemical leucoderma (Option D): Caused by exposure to certain chemicals (e.g., phenols), leading to destruction or functional inhibition of melanocytes.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a well-defined pale patch over the left upper arm since birth. The lesion becomes less visible when the surrounding skin is compressed. There is no scaling, sensory loss, or history of progression. Which of the following tests would best help differentiate nevus anemicus from depigmenting disorders?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The test that helps differentiate nevus anemicus from depigmenting disorders is Diascopy.

  • Technique: Pressing a glass slide or clear plastic against the skin to compress superficial blood vessels.
  • Purpose: Helps distinguish vascular from non-vascular lesions and evaluate underlying pigmentation.
  • Uses:
    • Granulomas (e.g., lupus vulgaris) appear as ‘apple jelly’ nodules on diascopy.
    • The margins of Naevus Depigmentosus remain distinct from normal skin during diascopy. While margins of Naevus Anemicus blend in with the surrounding skin, as normal skin also blanches on pressing with the slide
    • Lesion remains paler than the surrounding skin on diascopy due to melanin loss in Vitiligo.
    • In spider naevus, compressing surrounding vessels reveals a pulsatile central arteriole.

Reference: Office Techniques for Dermatologic Diagnosis

questions.text: The most commonly associated hormonal abnormality with this condition is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diagnosis of a patient with depigmented macules on the body - Vitiligo

  • Vitiligo is often associated with autoimmune diseases, particularly those involving the endocrine system. The most commonly associated hormonal abnormality is autoimmune thyroid disease, especially hypothyroidism. 

Other associations are:

  • Myasthenia gravis
  • Pernicious anemia

choices.text: Complete absence of melanocytes in association with a total loss of epidermal pigmentation
Superficial perivascular and perifollicular neutrophilic infiltrates
Normal number of melanocytes with loss of epidermal pigmentation

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with skin lesions as shown. A skin biopsy for histopathology was done from one of the chest lesions. Which of the following options will be the appropriate histological finding in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image represents a person with Vitiligo. So, complete absence of melanocytes in association with a total loss of epidermal pigmentation would be the appropriate histological finding in this condition.

  • Vitiligo is an acquired pigmentary disorder of the skin caused by the absence of pigment cells from the epidermis. It is characterised by milky-white, well-demarcated, multiple macules and patches on the body.
  • Histopathological examination of the involved skin shows a complete absence of melanocytes in association with a total loss of epidermal pigmentation.

choices.text: Vitiligo surgery is the treatment of choice for rapidly spreading vitiligo
Phototherapy is done in stable vitiligo
Facial lesions have poor prognostic value
Acral vitiligo is a good prognostic factor

questions.text: Which of the following is true about vitiligo?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The only true statement from the given options is that phototherapy is done in stable vitiligo

Prognosis:

  • Typically progressive, with periods of rapid spread and long phases of stability
  • Segmental vitiligo: Onset early in life, stabilises within 1 year
  • Spontaneous repigmentation may occur, often perifollicular and in sun-exposed areas

Prognosis better in

  1. Facial lesions (Option C ruled out)
  2. short disease duration,
  3. early treatment

Poor prognostic factors for vitiligo:

  1. Leucotrichia
  2. Lip tip variant
  3. Long-standing disease
  4. Thyroid abnormalities
  5. Vitiligo on a bony prominence
  6. Acral vitiligo (Option D ruled out)

Phototherapy

  • Narrowband UVB:
    1. More effective and safer than PUVA
    2. First-line treatment in generalised vitiligo
  • PUVA Therapy
    1. Used less commonly due to a higher risk of burns, tanning, and ocular complications
    2. Involves UVA exposure + oral/topical psoralens: Requires eye protection during phototherapy, may cause tanning of normal skin and burns, especially in skin types I & II

For stable vitiligo (no progression ≥6–12 months) (Option A ruled out), surgical management is considered.

  • Tissue grafts: Punch, split-thickness, suction blister grafts
  • Cellular grafts: Cultured/non-cultured melanocyte transfers, better for larger areas, better cosmetic results
  • Hair follicle outer root sheath melanocyte transfer

Systemic Therapies: Oral mini-pulse steroids, systemic JAK inhibitors, and other immunomodulators like methotrexate, minocycline

Supportive Therapy: Antioxidants, cosmetic camouflage, and sunscreen

Depigmentation Therapy: For extensive vitiligo with minimal residual pigment: 20% Monobenzyl ether of hydroquinone, laser (Q-switched), cryotherapy

questions.text: A 25-year-old female has a patch of vitiligo over the ankles. Which of the following is not used in treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fusidic acid is a topical antibiotic that doesn't have any role in vitiligo.

Topical agents used in the treatment of vitiligo are:

  • Topical steroid
    1. Clobetasol (Option B ruled out): Potent corticosteroid used in localised, stable vitiligo, not preferred on face or intertriginous areas due to side effects
  • Calcineurin inhibitors:
    1. Tacrolimus (Option A ruled out): Suppresses local immune response, used especially on the face and folds
    2. Pimecrolimus
  • Vitamin D analogs:
    1. Calcipotriol
  • Methoxsalen (Option C ruled out): A photosensitizer used in PUVA (Psoralen + UVA) therapy, induces pigmentation by stimulating melanocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of ultraviolet (UV) radiation and wavelength is incorrectly matched?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct pairs are

questions.text: A 48-year-old patient presents with well-defined depigmented patches on the dorsum of both feet. The lesions are asymptomatic and appear gradually over several months. She started wearing rubber slippers a year ago. The image of the lesion is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The picture depicts a case of contact leucoderma.

Contact Leukoderma

  • Definition: Acquired depigmentation caused by direct contact with melanocytotoxic chemicals, leading to melanocyte destruction.
  • Pathogenesis: No melanocytes are present in the lesion due to chemical-induced cytotoxicity.

Causative Agents:

  • Monobenzyl ether of hydroquinone (MBEH) is found in rubber gloves, slippers, and wallets.
  • Para-tertiary butylphenol (PTBP) – used in bindi adhesives.
  • Para-phenylenediamine (PPD) – found in hair dyes (the most common cosmetic cause).

Clinical Features:

  • Well-defined depigmented macules/patches at sites of tight and prolonged contact.
  • Asymptomatic, typically on hands, feet, or forehead (depending on exposure).

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical history and lesion pattern.
  • Wood’s lamp: accentuates depigmentation.
  • Histology: absence of melanocytes.

Management:

  • Immediate cessation of contact with the offending chemical.
  • Topical corticosteroids or calcineurin inhibitors may help in early cases.
  • Often difficult to treat; surgical interventions (e.g., melanocyte transfer) may be needed for repigmentation.

Explanation for other options:

Vitiligo: (Option A) Usually idiopathic and autoimmune; can appear anywhere, often bilateral, but not linked to contact areas.

Piebaldism: (Option B) Congenital, stable depigmentation usually on the midline and not acquired later in life.

Albinism: (Option C) Generalised congenital lack of melanin; not patchy or localised.

questions.text: A patient came for the removal of a tattoo. Which of the following devices can be used?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Q-switched Nd: YAG laser is the gold standard for tattoo removal due to its ability to deliver high-intensity pulses in nanoseconds.
  • They break down ink particles via a photomechanical effect
  • Target a variety of ink colours depending on wavelength:
    • 1064 nm: Black and dark blue tattoos
    • 532 nm: Red, orange, and yellow pigments

Explanation for other options:

Pulsed dye laser (Option A)  - Primarily used for vascular lesions and not tattoo ink.

KTP laser (532 nm) (Option C) - Useful for red pigments but limited in scope and not the first-line choice for most tattoo colours.

Diode laser (Option D) - Mostly used for hair removal and vascular lesions, not for tattoo removal.

questions.text: A patient with vitiligo universalis presents to you in the OPD. He wants the removal of a few pigmented lesions on the face to get a uniform skin colour. Which of the following medications can be prescribed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Monobenzyl ether of hydroquinone is the most commonly used depigmenting agent for Vitiligo

  • Depigmentation therapy refers to medical treatments that remove skin pigmentation, causing contact leukoderma.
  • Depigmentation therapy is used in someone who has widespread, but incomplete, vitiligo on the face and/or other sites, in an attempt to improve their appearance.
  • In vitiligo universalis, the patient has near-complete or complete depigmentation of the skin. Some patients may have residual pigmented patches, and for cosmetic reasons, they may wish to depigment these remaining areas to achieve a uniform skin tone.
  • The most commonly used depigmenting agent is monobenzyl ether of hydroquinone (MBEH). MBEH is a derivative of hydroquinone; it almost always causes irreversible depigmentation, as it results in the death of melanocytes.

Explanation for other options:

Melanocyl (Option A): Used for re-pigmentation in vitiligo, not for depigmentation.

Tacrolimus (Option C):  An immunomodulator used to promote re-pigmentation, especially in localised vitiligo.

Betamethasone (Option D):  A corticosteroid used to suppress inflammation and promote repigmentation in early vitiligo.

questions.text: A 13-year-old child presented with a unilateral depigmented lesion on the neck and chin associated with leucotrichia as given in the mage. Identify the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A unilateral depigmented lesion on the neck and chin associated with leucotrichia is attributed to Segmental Vitiligo. 

Explanation for other options:

Nevus anemicus (Option A): an area of pallor, not depigmented, does not have leucotrichia

Piebaldism (Option C): It has an autosomal dominant inheritance, associated with a white forelock of hair, not leucotrichia within the lesion

Nevus Depigmentosus (Option D): present at birth, size increases with age

questions.text: Which of the following is a true association?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Psoriasis is strongly linked with metabolic syndrome (MetS), which includes obesity, insulin resistance, hypertension, and dyslipidemia. The association between vitiligo and metabolic syndrome is less pronounced and not as well established as in psoriasis. (Option C ruled out)

  • Metabolic syndrome (MetS) is the most common comorbidity associated with psoriasis, and it significantly increases the risk of cardiovascular disease, which is a leading cause of mortality in psoriasis patients.
  • The IL-23/Th17 immune signalling pathway plays a central role in the pathogenesis of both psoriasis and metabolic syndrome.
  • Dysregulation of this pathway may contribute to increased susceptibility to metabolic and cardiovascular diseases, both in individuals with psoriasis and in the general population.
  • Melasma is benign hyperpigmentation with no malignant potential. (Option B ruled out)
  • Lichen planus is not associated with malignant melanoma, though rarely linked to squamous cell carcinoma (especially oral LP). (Option A ruled out)

Reference: Psoriasis and metabolic syndrome: implications for the management and treatment of psoriasis

questions.text: Based on the image given below, what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given picture depicts cutaneous changes in Hypomelanosis of Ito.

Hypomelanosis of Ito (HMI) is a rare neurocutaneous disorder characterised by:

  • Skin abnormalities: Hypopigmented macules, streaks, and whorls following the lines of Blaschko, appearing unilaterally or bilaterally.
  • Neurological involvement: Commonly associated with intellectual disability and epilepsy.
  • Extracutaneous manifestations: May include ophthalmological and skeletal defects.

It is also known as incontinentia pigmenti achromians.

Explanation for other options:

Segmental Vitiligo: (Option D)

  • A localised form of vitiligo with unilateral depigmented patches.
  • Follows a segmental or dermatomal distribution, and rarely crosses the midline.
  • Commonly involves the face, trunk, or limbs.
  • Often associated with leukotrichia (white hair in affected areas).
  • Diagnosis: Wood’s lamp accentuates depigmented patches.
  • Less responsive to phototherapy compared to non-segmental vitiligo, topical steroids, or calcineurin inhibitors may help in early active lesions.

questions.text: A young female presents with multiple small light brown macules on her cheeks that become darker during summer and fade in winter. The lesions are limited to sun-exposed areas and are pinhead-sized. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Multiple small light brown macules that become darker during summer and fade in winter are a classical explanation for Freckles.

  • Melasma (Option C): It is a common, acquired, circumscribed pigmentation in sun-exposed skin. It presents as symmetric, hyperpigmented macules having irregular, serrated borders. Melasma is typically larger, symmetric, and persistent, not seasonal like freckles.
  • Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (Option D): Occurs after skin injury/inflammation (acne, eczema, trauma) as brown or black macules/patches at the site of the previous lesion. The pigmentation is not seasonal and localised to sun-exposed areas.

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes is not associated with albinism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Waardenburg syndrome involves piebaldism with features of hearing loss and white forelock, but not true albinism.

Explanation for other options:

Chediak-Higashi syndrome (Option A): Autosomal recessive disorder with albinism, recurrent infections, and giant granules in neutrophils.

Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome (Option B): Autosomal recessive disorder with albinism, platelet dysfunction, and ceroid deposition.

Griscelli syndrome (Option C): Autosomal recessive disorder with albinism, silver hair, and immunodeficiency.
